title: First State first in for Latitude Financial Group
text:
The $90 billion industry fund dubbed "the mini AustralianSuper" is set to be one of consumer finance business Latitude Financial Group's biggest institutional shareholders.

Street Talk understands Sydney-based First State Super is sitting on a Latitude stake worth about $100 million, that would convert into ordinary shares as part of the company's float and be escrowed until at least this time next year.

It is understood First State picked up the stake from Deutsche Bank, which is one of Latitude's three major shareholders and took some money off the table by selling down its economic interest in the business as Street Talk reported last week.

The selldown was in three parcels - sales to two institutional investors, and a family office tranche.

First State is believed to be one of the institutions, while the other is Credit Suisse Asset Management. Credit Suisse has since passed the stake on SPF Investment Management, which was spun out of the Swisse bank.

Together the "minority investors" would own 9 per cent of the listed Latitude worth about $350 million, according to an offer structure in front of potential investors.

It's another big move by First State, which is proving to be an active dealmakers in Australian capital markets. The industry fund rocketed on to dealmakers' radars when it paid $1 billion for NSW's financial planning business State Plus in 2016 and has been an active equity syndicate member in recent asset auctions.
description: The industry fund dubbed "the mini AustralianSuper" is set to be one of Latitude's biggest institutional shareholders.
